article.paragraph: Ayn Rand(IPAc-enˈaɪn_ˈrænd;harvnbBranden198671;harvnbGladstein19999bornAlisa Zinov'yevna Rosenbaum,lang-ruАли́са Зино́вьевна Розенба́ум;OldStyleDateFebruary 21905January 20  March 6, 1982) was a Russian-born Americannovelist, philosopher,harvnbDen UylRasmussen1986x;harvnbSciabarra19951–2;harvnbKukathas199855;harvnbBadhwarLong2010.playwright, and screenwriter. She is known for her two best-selling novels,The FountainheadandAtlas Shrugged, and for developing a philosophical system she calledObjectivism (Ayn Rand)Objectivism. Born and educated inRussian AmericanRussia, Rand moved to the United States in 1926. She had a play produced on Broadway in 19351936. After two early novels that were initially unsuccessful in America, she achieved fame with her 1943 novel,The Fountainhead.

In 1957, she published her best-known work, the novelAtlas Shrugged. Afterward, she turned to non-fiction to promote her philosophy, publishing her own magazines and releasing several collections of essays until her death in 1982. Rand advocatedreasonas the only means of acquiringknowledgeand rejected faith and religion. She supportedrational egoismrationalandethical egoism, and rejectedAltruism (ethics)altruism. In politics, she condemned theinitiation of forceas immoralharvnbBarry1987122;harvnbPeikoff1991309–314;harvnbSciabarra1995298;harvnbGotthelf200091;harvnbGladstein200946and opposedcollectivismandstatismas well asanarchism, instead supportinglaissez-fairecapitalism, which she defined as the system based on recognizingindividual rights.harvnbGotthelf200091–92;harvnbPeikoff1991379–380In art, Rand promotedromantic realism. She was sharply critical of most philosophers and philosophical traditions known to her, except forAristotleand someAristotelianismAristoteliansandclassical liberals.harvnbO'Neill197718–20;harvnbSciabarra199512, 118

Literary critics received Rand's fiction with mixed reviews,harvnbGladstein1999117–119and academia generally ignored or rejected her philosophy, though academic interest has increased in recent decades.cite newsCohenDavidhttp://www.theguardian.com/education/2001/dec/07/internationaleducationnews.highereducationA growing concern[[The Guardian]]December 7, 2001LondonApril 15, 2011cite newsMarcusJonhttp://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/407357.articleAyn Rand revival gathers pace in US universities, despite detractorsTimes Higher EducationJuly 16, 2009April 4, 2014harvnbBadhwarLong2010TheObjectivist movementattempts to spread her ideas, both to the public and in academic settings.harvnbSciabarra19951–2She has been a significant influence amonglibertariansandConservatism in the United StatesAmerican conservatives.harvnbBurns20094;harvnbGladstein2009107–108, 124
article.heading: Life
Early life
article.paragraph: Rand was born Alisa Zinov'yevna Rosenbaum (lang-ruАли́са Зиновьевна Розенбаум) on February 2, 1905, to aRussian JewishbourgeoisharvnbHeller2009xiiifamily living inSaint Petersburg. She was the eldest of the three daughters of Zinovy Zakharovich Rosenbaum and his wife, Anna Borisovna (ne Kaplan), largely non-observantJews. Zinovy Rosenbaum was a successful pharmacist and businessman, eventually owning a pharmacy and the building in which it was located.harvnbHeller20093–5;harvnbBritting20042–3;harvnbBurns20099With a passion for the liberal arts, Rand later said she found school unchallenging and she began writing screenplays at the age of eight and novels at the age of ten.cite episodeThe Tomorrow ShowTom SnyderNBCJuly 2, 1979At the prestigious Stoiunina Gymnasium, her closest friend wasVladimir Nabokov's younger sister, Olga. The two girls shared an intense interest in politics and would engage in debates at theNabokov houseNabokov mansion: while Nabokov defended constitutional monarchy, Rand supported republican ideals.harvnbSciabarra199569, 367–8;harvnbGladstein20092She was twelve at the time of theFebruary Revolutionof 1917, during which she favoredAlexander KerenskyoverTsarNicholas II.

The subsequentOctober Revolutionand the rule of theBolsheviksunderVladimir Lenindisrupted the life the family had previously enjoyed. Her fathers business was confiscated and the family displaced. They fled to theCrimean Peninsula, which was initially under control of theWhite Armyduring theRussian Civil War. She later recalled that, while in high school, she determined that she was anatheistand that she valuedreasonabove any other human virtue. After graduating from high school in the Crimea at 16, Rand returned with her family to Petrograd (as Saint Petersburg was renamed at that time), where they faced desperate conditions, on occasion nearly starving.harvnbBranden198635–39harvnbBritting200414–20

File:Spb 06-2012 University Embankment 06.jpgthumbleftalt=The Twelve Collegia of what was then Petrograd State UniversityRand completed a three-year program atPetrograd State University.After the Russian Revolution, universities were opened to women, allowing Rand to be in the first group of women to enroll atPetrograd State University,harvnbBurns200915where, at the age of 16, she began her studies in the department ofsocial pedagogy, majoring in history.harvnbSciabarra199577At the university she was introduced to the writings ofAristotleandPlato,harvnbSciabarra19995–8who would be her greatest influence and counter-influence, respectively.harvnbHeller200941;harvnbPeikoff1991451–460A third figure whose philosophical works she studied heavily wasFriedrich Nietzsche.harvnbBritting200417–18, 22–24Able to read French, German and Russian, Rand also discovered the writersFyodor Dostoevsky,Victor Hugo,Edmond Rostand, andFriedrich Schiller, who became her perennial favorites.harvnbBritting200417, 22

Along with many other "bourgeois" students, Rand was purged from the university shortly before graduating. However, after complaints from a group of visiting foreign scientists, many of the purged students were allowed to complete their work and graduate,harvnbHeller200947;harvnbBritting200424which Rand did in October 1924.harvnbSciabarra19991She subsequently studied for a year at the StateTechnicumfor Screen Arts in Leningrad. For one of her assignments, she wrote an essay about the Polish-American actressPola Negri, which became her first published work.harvnbHeller200949–50

By this time she had decided her professional surname for writing would beRand,harvnbBritting200433possibly as aCyrilliccontraction of her birth surname,harvnbGladstein20097;harvnbHeller200955and she adopted the first nameAyn, either from aFinnish languageFinnishnameAino (given name)Ainoor from theHebrewwordlangheעין(ayin, meaning "eye").Rand said the origin ofAynwas FinnishharvRand199540, but some biographical sources question this, suggesting it may come from a Hebrew nickname.harvnbHeller200955–57provides a detailed discussion.
article.heading: Arrival in the United States
article.paragraph: File:Pola Negri by Ayn Rand cover.jpgthumbuprightalt=A brown book cover with black-and-white drawings and text in Russian. The drawing on the left is a portrait of a woman with dark hair; the drawing on the right is of skyscrapers.Cover of Rand's first published work, a 2,500-word monograph on ''femme fatale''Pola Negripublished in 1925.In the autumn of 1925, Rand was granted aVisa (document)visato visit American relatives.harvnbBranden198632;harvnbBurns200918–19She departed on January 17, 1926.harvnbHeller200950–51When she arrived in New York City on February 19, 1926, she was so impressed with the skyline ofManhattanthat she cried what she later called "tears of splendor".harvnbHeller200953Intent on staying in the United States to become a screenwriter, she lived for a few months with relatives inChicago, one of whom owned a movie theater and allowed her to watch dozens of films for free. She then set out forHollywood, California.harvnbHeller200957–60

Initially, Rand struggled in Hollywood and took odd jobs to pay her basic living expenses. A chance meeting with famed directorCecil B. DeMilleled to a job as anextra (drama)extrain his filmThe King of Kings (1927 film)The King of Kingsas well as subsequent work as a junior screenwriter.harvnbBritting200434–36While working onThe King of Kings, she met an aspiring young actor, Frank O'Connor; the two were married on April 15, 1929, around the time her last visa extension was set to expire. She became aPermanent residence (United States)permanent US residentin July 1929, andUnited States nationality law#Naturalizationbecame an American citizenon March 3, 1931.harvnbBritting200439;harvnbHeller200971Taking various jobs during the 1930s to support her writing, she worked for a time as the head of the costume department atRKOStudios.harvnbBritting200435–40;harvnbPaxton199874, 81, 84She made several attempts to bring her parents and sisters to the United States, but they were unable to acquire permission to emigrate.harvnbHeller200996–98;harvnbBritting200443–44, 52
article.heading: Early fiction
article.paragraph: See alsoNight of January 16thWe the LivingAnthem (novella)Rand's first literary success came with the sale of her screenplayRed PawntoUniversal Studiosin 1932, although it was never produced.harvnbBritting200440, 42This was followed by the courtroom dramaNight of January 16th, first produced byE.E. Clivein Hollywood in 1934 and then successfully reopened onBroadway theaterBroadwayin 1935. Each night the "jury" was selected from members of the audience, and one of the two different endings, depending on the jury's "verdict", would then be performed.harvnbHeller200976, 92In 1941,Paramount Picturesproduced aThe Night of January 16th (film)movie loosely based on the play. Rand did not participate in the production and was highly critical of the result.harvnbHeller200978;harvnbGladstein200987Ideal (novel)Idealis a novel and play written in 1934 which were first published in 2015 by her estate. The heroine is an actress who embodies Randian ideals.cite newsMichiko KakutaniReview: Ayn Rand’s ‘Ideal’ Presents a Protagonist Familiar in Her Superiorityhttp://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/11/books/review-ayn-rands-ideal-presents-a-protagonist-familiar-in-her-superiority.htmlAugust 11, 2015The New York TimesAugust 10, 2015

Rand's first published novel, the semi-autobiographicalWe the Living, was published in 1936. Set inSoviet Russia, it focused on the struggle between the individual and the state. In a 1959 foreword to the novel, Rand stated thatWe the Living"is as near to an autobiography as I will ever write. It is not an autobiography in the literal, but only in the intellectual sense. The plot is invented, the background is not..."cite bookRandAynForewordWe the LivingNew YorkDuttonxviii0-525-94054-53278045860th Anniversary19951936Initial sales were slow and the American publisher let it go out of print,harvnbGladstein200913although European editions continued to sell.Ralston, Richard E. "PublishingWe the Living". InharvnbMayhew2004141After the success of her later novels, Rand was able to release a revised version in 1959 that has since sold over three million copies.Ralston, Richard E. "PublishingWe the Living". InharvnbMayhew2004143In 1942, without Rand's knowledge or permission, the novel was made into a pair of Italian films,Noi viviandAddio, Kira. Rediscovered in the 1960s, these films were re-edited into a new version which was approved by Rand and re-released asWe the Living (film)We the Livingin 1986.harvnbPaxton1998104

Her novellaAnthem (novella)Anthemwas written during a break from the writing of her next major novel,The Fountainhead. It presents a vision of adystopianfuture world in whichtotalitariancollectivism has triumphed to such an extent that even the word 'I' has been forgotten and replaced with 'we'.harvnbBurns200950;harvnbHeller2009102It was published in England in 1938, but Rand initially could not find an American publisher. As withWe the Living, Rand's later success allowed her to get a revised version published in 1946, which has sold more than 3.5 million copies.Ralston, Richard E. "PublishingAnthem". InharvnbMayhew2005a24–27
article.heading: The Fountainheadand political activism
article.paragraph: See alsoThe FountainheadThe Fountainhead (film)During the 1940s, Rand became politically active. Both she and her husband worked full-time in volunteer positions for the 1940 presidential campaign of RepublicanWendell Willkie. This work led to Rand's first public speaking experiences, including fielding the sometimes hostile questions from New York City audiences who had just viewed pro-Willkienewsreels, an experience she greatly enjoyed.harvnbBritting200457This activity also brought her into contact with other intellectuals sympathetic to free-market capitalism. She became friends with journalistHenry Hazlittand his wife, and Hazlitt introduced her to theAustrian SchooleconomistLudwig von Mises. Despite her philosophical differences with them, Rand strongly endorsed the writings of both men throughout her career, and both of them expressed admiration for her. Once Mises referred to Rand as "the most courageous man in America", a compliment that particularly pleased her because he said "man" instead of "woman".harvnbBurns2009114;harvnbHeller2009249;harvnbBranden1986188–189Rand also developed a friendship with libertarian writerIsabel Paterson. Rand questioned the well-informed Paterson about American history and politics long into the night during their numerous meetings and gave Paterson ideas for her only nonfiction book,The God of the Machine.harvnbBurns200975–78

Rand's first major success as a writer came withThe Fountainheadin 1943, a romantic and philosophical novel that she wrote over a period of seven years.harvnbBritting200461–78The novel centers on an uncompromising young architect namedHoward Roarkand his struggle against what Rand described as "second-handers"those who attempt to live through others, placing others above themselves. It was rejected by twelve publishers before finally being accepted by theBobbs-Merrill Companyon the insistence of editor Archibald Ogden, who threatened to quit if his employer did not publish it.harvnbBritting200458–61While completing the novel, Rand was prescribedBenzedrine, a brand ofamphetamine, to fight fatigue.harvnbBurns200985The drug helped her to work long hours to meet her deadline for delivering the finished novel, but when the book was done, she was so exhausted that her doctor ordered two weeks' rest.harvnbBurns200989Her use of the drug for approximately three decades may have contributed to what some of her later associates described as volatile mood swings.harvnbBurns2009178;harvnbHeller2009304–305

The Fountainheadeventually became a worldwide success, bringing Rand fame and financial security.harvnbDoherty2007149;harvnbBranden1986180–181In 1943, Rand sold the rights for aThe Fountainhead (film)film versiontoWarner Bros., and she returned to Hollywood to write the screenplay. Finishing her work on that screenplay, she was hired by producerHal Wallisas a screenwriter and script-doctor. Her work for Wallis included the screenplays for theAcademy AwardOscar-nominatedLove Letters (1945 film)Love LettersandYou Came Along.harvnbBritting200468–80;harvnbBranden1986183–198This role gave Rand time to work on other projects, including a planned nonfiction treatment of her philosophy to be calledThe Moral Basis of Individualism. Although the planned book was never completed, a condensed version was published as an essay titled "The Only Path to Tomorrow", in the January 1944 edition ofReader's Digestmagazine.harvnbSciabarra1995112;harvnbHeller2009171

WikisourceAyn Rand's testimony before the House of Representatives Committee on Un-American ActivitiesRand extended her involvement with free-market andanti-communistactivism while working in Hollywood. She became involved with theMotion Picture Alliance for the Preservation of American Ideals, a Hollywood anti-Communist group, and wrote articles on the group's behalf. She also joined the anti-CommunistAmerican Writers Association.harvnbBurns2009100–101, 123A visit by Isabel Paterson to meet with Rand's California associates led to a final falling out between the two when Paterson made comments to valued political allies, which Rand considered rude.harvnbBurns2009130–131;harvnbHeller2009214–215In 1947, during theSecond Red Scare, Rand testified as a "friendly witness" before the United StatesHouse Un-American Activities Committee. Her testimony described the disparity between her personal experiences in theSoviet Unionand the portrayal of it in the 1944 filmSong of Russia.harvnbMayhew2005b91–93Rand argued that the film grossly misrepresented conditions in the Soviet Union, portraying life there as being much better and happier than it actually was.harvnbMayhew2005b188–189She wanted to also criticize the lauded 1946 filmThe Best Years of Our Livesfor what she interpreted as its negative presentation of the business world, but she was not allowed to testify about it.harvnbBurns2009125When asked after the hearings about her feelings on the effectiveness of the investigations, Rand described the process as "futile".harvnbMayhew2005b83

After several delays, the film version ofThe Fountainheadwas released in 1949. Although it used Rand's screenplay with minimal alterations, she "disliked the movie from beginning to end", complaining about its editing, acting, and other elements.harvnbBritting200471
article.heading: Atlas Shruggedand Objectivism
article.paragraph: See alsoAtlas ShruggedObjectivism (Ayn Rand)Objectivist movementIn the years following the publication ofThe Fountainhead, Rand received numerous letters from readers, some of whom it profoundly influenced. In 1951 Rand moved from Los Angeles to New York City, where she gathered a group of these admirers around her. This group (jokingly designated "The Collective") included futureFederal Reserve ChairmanAlan Greenspan, a young psychology student named Nathan Blumenthal (laterNathaniel Branden) and his wifeBarbara BrandenBarbara, and Barbara's cousinLeonard Peikoff. At first the group was an informal gathering of friends who met with Rand on weekends at her apartment to discuss philosophy. Later she began allowing them to read the drafts of her new novel,Atlas Shrugged, as the manuscript pages were written. In 1954 Rand's close relationship with the younger Nathaniel Branden turned into a romantic affair, with the consent of their spouses.harvnbBranden1986256–264, 331–343

Atlas Shrugged, published in 1957, was considered Rand'smagnum opus.harvnbSciabarra1995113;harvnbMayhew2005b78Rand described the theme of the novel as "the role of the mind in man's existenceand, as a corollary, the demonstration of a new moral philosophy: the morality of rational self-interest."Salmieri, Gregory. "Atlas Shruggedon the Role of the Mind in Man's Existence". InharvnbMayhew2009248It advocates the core tenets of Rand's philosophy ofObjectivism (Ayn Rand)Objectivismand expresses her concept of human achievement. The plot involves adystopianUnited States in which the most creative industrialists, scientists, and artists go onstrike actionstrikeand retreat to a mountainous hideaway where they build an independent free economy. The novel's hero and leader of the strike,John Galt, describes the strike as "stopping the motor of the world" by withdrawing the minds of the individuals most contributing to the nation's wealth and achievement. With this fictional strike, Rand intended to illustrate that without the efforts of the rational and productive, the economy would collapse and society would fall apart. The novel includes elements ofRomance novelromance,cite newsDowdMaureenMaureen DowdAtlas Without Angelinahttp://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/17/opinion/17dowd.htmlApril 17, 2011[[New York Times]]July 30, 2012harvnbMcConnell2010507mystery (fiction)mystery, andscience fiction,harvnbGladstein199942and it contains Rand's most extensive statement of Objectivism in any of her works of fiction, a lengthy monologue delivered by Galt.

Despite many negative reviews,Atlas Shruggedbecame an international bestseller, and in an interview withMike Wallace, Rand declared herself "the most creative thinker alive".harvnbBurns20092After completing the novel, Rand fell into a severe depression.harvnbBurns2009178;harvnbHeller2009303–306Atlas Shruggedwas Rand's last completed work of fiction; a turning point in her life, it marked the end of Rand's career as a novelist and the beginning of her role as a popular philosopher.harvnbGladstein200028;harvnbYounkins20071;harvnbBaker198717

In 1958 Nathaniel Branden established Nathaniel Branden Lectures, later incorporated as theNathaniel Branden Institute(NBI), to promote Rand's philosophy. Collective members gave lectures for NBI and wrote articles forObjectivist periodicalsthat she edited. Rand later published some of these articles in book form. Critics, including some former NBI students and Branden himself, have described the culture of NBI as one of intellectual conformity and excessive reverence for Rand, with some describing NBI or theObjectivist movementitself as acultor religion.harvnbGladstein2009105–106;harvnbBurns2009232–233Rand expressed opinions on a wide range of topics, from literature and music to sexuality and facial hair, and some of her followers mimicked her preferences, wearing clothes to match characters from her novels and buying furniture like hers.harvnbBurns2009236–237Rand was unimpressed with many of the NBI studentsharvnbHeller2009303and held them to strict standards, sometimes reacting coldly or angrily to those who disagreed with her.harvnbDoherty2007237–238;harvnbHeller2009329;harvnbBurns2009235However, some former NBI students believe the extent of these behaviors has been exaggerated, with the problem being concentrated among Rand's closest followers in New York.harvnbDoherty2007235;harvnbBurns2009235
article.heading: Later years
article.paragraph: Throughout the 1960s and 1970s, Rand developed and promoted her Objectivist philosophy through her nonfiction works and by giving talks to students at institutions such asYale,Princeton UniversityPrinceton,Columbia UniversityColumbia,harvnbBranden1986315–316Harvard, andMIT.harvnbGladstein199914She received an honorary doctorate fromLewis & Clark Collegein 1963.harvnbBranden1986318She also began delivering annual lectures at theFord Hall Forum, responding afterward to questions from the audience.harvnbGladstein199916During these speeches and Q&A sessions, she often took controversial stances on political and social issues of the day. These included supporting abortion rights,harvnbHeller2009320–321opposing theVietnam Warand themilitary draft(but condemning manydraft dodgersas "bums"),harvnbBurns2009228–229, 265;harvnbHeller2009352supportingIsraelin theYom Kippur Warof 1973 against a coalition of Arab nations as "civilized men fighting savages",harvnbRand200596;harvnbBurns2009266sayingEuropean colonization of the AmericasEuropean colonistshad the right to develop land taken fromIndigenous peoples of the AmericasAmerican Indians,harvnbBurns2009266;harvnbHeller2009391and callinghomosexuality"immoral" and "disgusting", while also advocating the repeal of all laws about it.harvnbHeller2009362, 519She also endorsed severalRepublican Party (United States)Republicancandidates for President of the United States, most stronglyBarry GoldwaterinUnited States presidential election, 19641964, whose candidacy she promoted in several articles forThe Objectivist Newsletter.harvnbBurns2009204–206;harvnbHeller2009322–323File:Ayn Rand Marker.jpgthumbleftGrave marker for Rand and her husband atKensico CemeteryinValhalla, New Yorkalt=A twin gravestone bearing the name "Frank O'Connor" on the left, and "Ayn Rand O'Connor" on the rightIn 1964 Nathaniel Branden began an affair with the young actress Patrecia Scott, whom he later married. Nathaniel and Barbara Branden kept the affair hidden from Rand. When she learned of it in 1968, though her romantic relationship with Branden had already ended,harvnbBritting2004101Rand terminated her relationship with both Brandens, which led to the closure of NBI.harvnbBranden1986344–358Rand published an article inThe Objectivistrepudiating Nathaniel Branden for dishonesty and other "irrational behavior in his private life".harvnbHeller2009378–379Branden later apologized in an interview to "every student of Objectivism" for "perpetuating the Ayn Rand mystique" and for "contributing to that dreadful atmosphere of intellectual repressiveness that pervades the Objectivist movement."harvnbHeller2009411In subsequent years, Rand and several more of her closest associates parted company.harvnbBranden1986386–389

Rand underwent surgery forlung cancerin 1974 after decades of heavy smoking.harvnbHeller2009391–393In 1976, she retired from writing her newsletter and, despite her initial objections, allowed Evva Pryor, a social worker from her attorney's office, to enroll her inSocial Security (United States)Social SecurityandMedicare (United States)Medicare.harvnbMcConnell2010520–521harvnbWeiss201262During the late 1970s her activities within the Objectivist movement declined, especially after the death of her husband on November 9, 1979.harvnbBranden1986392–395One of her final projects was work on a never-completed television adaptation ofAtlas Shrugged.harvnbHeller2009406

Rand died ofheart failureon March 6, 1982, at her home in New York City,harvnbHeller2009410and was interred in theKensico Cemetery,Valhalla, New York.harvnbHeller2009405, 410Rand's funeral was attended by some of her prominent followers, includingAlan Greenspan. Aconvert6ftmonfloral arrangement in the shape of a dollar sign was placed near her casket.harvnbBranden1986403In her will, Rand namedLeonard Peikoffthe heir to her estate.harvnbHeller2009400
article.heading: Philosophy
article.paragraph: Objectivist movementMainObjectivism (Ayn Rand)Rand called her philosophy "Objectivism", describing its essence as "the concept of man as a heroic being, with his own happiness as the moral purpose of his life, with productive achievement as his noblest activity, and reason as his only absolute."harvnbRand19921170–1171She considered Objectivism asystematic philosophyand laid out positions onmetaphysics,epistemology,ethics,political philosophyandaesthetics.harvnbPeikoff19912–3;harvnbDen UylRasmussen1986224;harvnbGladsteinSciabarra19992

In metaphysics, Rand supportedphilosophical realism, and opposed anything she regarded as mysticism or supernaturalism, including all forms of religion.Den Uyl, Douglas J. & Rasmussen, Douglas B. "Ayn Rand's Realism". InharvnbDen UylRasmussen19863–20

Inepistemology, she considered all knowledge to be based on sense perception, the validity of which she consideredaxiomatic,harvnbPeikoff199138–39;harvnbGotthelf200054andreason, which she described as "the faculty that identifies and integrates the material provided by man's senses."harvnbRand196422She rejected all claims of non-perceptual orA priori and a posterioria prioriknowledge, including "'instinct,' 'intuition,' 'revelation,' or any form of 'just knowing.' "harvnbRand198262–63Rand argued that the requirements of cognition determine the objective criteria of conceptualization, which she summarized in the form of aRazor (philosophy)philosophical razor. Known as "Rand's razor," it states that "concepts are not to be multiplied beyond necessitythe corollary of which is: nor are they to be integrated in disregard of necessity."cite webRand's Razor[[The Ayn Rand Lexicon]]http://aynrandlexicon.com/lexicon/rands_razor.html2015-05-30In herIntroduction to Objectivist Epistemology, Rand presented a theory of concept formation and rejected theanalyticsynthetic dichotomy.harvnbSalmieriGotthelf20051997;harvnbGladstein199985–86

In ethics, Rand argued forrational egoismrationalandethical egoism(rational self-interest), as the guiding moral principle. She said the individual should "exist for his own sake, neither sacrificing himself to others nor sacrificing others to himself."harvnbRand19893She referred to egoism as "the virtue of selfishness" in herThe Virtue of Selfishnessbook of that title,harvnbKukathas199855in which she presented her solution to theis-ought problemby describing ameta-ethicaltheory that based morality in the needs of "man's survivalquaman".harvnbRand196425;harvnbBadhwarLong2010;harvnbPeikoff1991207, 219She condemned ethical altruism as incompatible with the requirements of human life and happiness,and held that theinitiation of forcewas evil and irrational, writing inAtlas Shruggedthat "Force and mind are opposites."harvnbRand19921023;harvnbPeikoff1991313–320

Rand's political philosophy emphasizedindividual rights(includingPrivate propertyproperty rights),harvnbPeikoff1991350–352and she consideredlaissez-fairecapitalismthe only moral social system because in her view it was the only system based on the protection of those rights.She opposedstatism, which she understood to includetheocracy,absolute monarchy,Nazism,fascism,communism,democratic socialism, anddictatorship.harvnbPeikoff1991369Rand believed that natural rights should be enforced by a constitutionally limited government.harvnbPeikoff1991367Although her political views are often classified asConservatism in the United Statesconservativeorlibertarian, she preferred the term "radical for capitalism". She worked with conservatives on political projects, but disagreed with them over issues such as religion and ethics.harvnbBurns2009174–177, 209, 230–231;harvnbDen UylRasmussen1986225–226;harvnbDoherty2007189–190;harvnbBranden1986252She denounced libertarianism, which she associated withanarchism.harvnbSciabarra1995266–267;harvnbBurns2009268–269She rejected anarchism as a nave theory based insubjectivismthat could only lead to collectivism in practice.harvnbSciabarra1995280–281;harvnbPeikoff1991371–372;harvnbMerrill1991139

Rand's aesthetics defined art as a "selective re-creation of reality according to an artist's metaphysical value-judgments." According to Rand, art allows philosophical concepts to be presented in a concrete form that can be easily grasped, thereby fulfilling a need of human consciousness.harvnbSciabarra1995204–205As a writer, the art form Rand focused on most closely was literature, where she consideredromanticismto be the approach that most accurately reflected the existence of humanfree will.harvnbPeikoff1991428She described her own approach to literature as "romantic realism".harvnbSciabarra1995207;harvnbPeikoff1991437

Rand acknowledgedAristotleas her greatest influenceharvnbRand19921171and remarked that in thehistory of philosophyshe could only recommend "three A's"Aristotle,Aquinas, and Ayn Rand.harvnbSciabarra199512In a 1959 interview withMike Wallace, when asked where her philosophy came from, she responded, "Out of my own mind, with the sole acknowledgement of a debt to Aristotle, the only philosopher who ever influenced me. I devised the rest of my philosophy myself."harvnbPodritskeSchwartz2009174–175However, she also found early inspiration inFriedrich Nietzsche,harvnbHeller200942;harvnbBurns200916, 22;harvnbSciabarra1995100–106and scholars have found indications of his influence in early notes from Rand's journals,harvnbRand199721;harvnbBurns200924–25;harvnbSciabarra1998136, 138–139in passages from the first edition ofWe the Living(which Rand later revised),harvnbMerrill199138–39;harvnbSciabarra1998135; Loiret-Prunet, Valerie. "Ayn Rand and Feminist Synthesis: RereadingWe the Living". InharvnbGladsteinSciabarra199997and in her overall writing style.harvnbBadhwarLong2010; Sheaffer, Robert. "Rereading Rand on Gender in the Light of Paglia". InharvnbGladsteinSciabarra1999313.However, by the time she wroteThe Fountainhead, Rand had turned against Nietzsche's ideas,harvnbBurns200941, 68;harvnbHeller200942;harvnbMerrill199147–49and the extent of his influence on her even during her early years is disputed.harvnbBurns2009303–304;harvnbSciabarra1998135, 137–138; Mayhew, Robert. "We the Living'36 and '59". InharvnbMayhew2004205.Among the philosophers Rand held in particular disdain wasImmanuel Kant, whom she referred to as a "monster",harvnbRand19714although philosophers George WalshharvnbWalsh2000and Fred SeddonharvnbSeddon200363–81have argued that she misinterpreted Kant and exaggerated their differences.

Rand said her most important contributions to philosophy were her "theory of concepts, [her] ethics, and [her] discovery in politics that evilthe violation of rightsconsists of the initiation of force."harvnbRand2005166She believed epistemology was a foundational branch of philosophy and considered the advocacy of reason to be the single most significant aspect of her philosophy,cite book[[Return of the Primitive: The Anti-Industrial Revolution]]The Left: Old and New620-452-01184-1392818361999New YorkMeridianRandAynEdited by Peter Schwartzstating, "I am notprimarilyan advocate of capitalism, but of egoism; and I am notprimarilyan advocate of egoism, but of reason. If one recognizes the supremacy of reason and applies it consistently, all the rest follows."harvnbRand19711

article.heading: Reviews
article.paragraph: During Rand's lifetime, her work evoked both extreme praise and condemnation. Rand's first novel,We the Living, was admired by the literary criticH. L. Mencken,harvnbRand199510, 13–14her Broadway playNight of January 16thwas both a critical and popular success,harvnbBranden1986122–124andThe Fountainheadwas hailed by a reviewer inThe New York Timesas "masterful".cite newsLorinePruetteThe New York TimesMay 16, 1943Battle Against EvilBR7http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?resApril 15, 2011http://web.archive.org/web/20110511114039/http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?resMay 11, 2011noReprinted incite bookBooks of the CenturyCharlesMcGrath1998New YorkTimes Books0-8129-2965-938439024135–136Rand's novels were derided by some critics when they were first published as being long and melodramatic.However, they becamebestsellerslargely through word of mouth.harvnbPaxton1998120;harvnbBritting200487

The first reviews Rand received were forNight of January 16th. Reviews of the production were largely positive, but Rand considered even positive reviews to be embarrassing because of significant changes made to her script by the producer.Rand believed that her first novel,We the Living, was not widely reviewed, but Rand scholar Michael S. Berliner says "it was the most reviewed of any of her works", with approximately 125 different reviews being published in more than 200 publications. Overall these reviews were more positive than the reviews she received for her later work.Berliner, Michael S. "Reviews ofWe the Living". InharvnbMayhew2004147–151Her 1938 novellaAnthemreceived little attention from reviewers, both for its first publication in England and for subsequent re-issues.Berliner, Michael S. "Reviews ofAnthem". InharvnbMayhew2005a55–60

Rand's first bestseller,The Fountainhead, received far fewer reviews thanWe the Living, and reviewers' opinions were mixed.Berliner, Michael S. "The FountainheadReviews". InharvnbMayhew200677–82There was a positive review inThe New York Timesthat Rand greatly appreciated.harvnbRand199574The reviewer called Rand "a writer of great power" who wrote "brilliantly, beautifully and bitterly", and stated that "you will not be able to read this masterful book without thinking through some of the basic concepts of our time".There were other positive reviews, but Rand dismissed most of them as either not understanding her message or as being from unimportant publications.Some negative reviews focused on the length of the novel,such as one that called it "a whale of a book" and another that said "anyone who is taken in by it deserves a stern lecture on paper-rationing". Other negative reviews called the characters unsympathetic and Rand's style "offensively pedestrian".

Rand's 1957 novelAtlas Shruggedwas widely reviewed, and many of the reviews were strongly negative.Berliner, Michael S. "TheAtlas ShruggedReviews". InharvnbMayhew2009133–137In theNational Review, conservative authorWhittaker Chamberscalled the book "sophomoric" and "remarkably silly". He described the tone of the book as "shrillness without reprieve" and accused Rand of supporting a godless system (which he related to that of theReligion in the Soviet UnionSoviets), claiming "From almost any page ofAtlas Shrugged, a voice can be heard, from painful necessity, commanding: 'To a gas chambergo!' "cite journalChambersWhittakerWhittaker ChambersBig Sister is Watching You[[National Review]]594–596http://www.nationalreview.com/articles/222482/big-sister-watching-you/flashbackDecember 8, 1957April 15, 2011http://web.archive.org/web/20110511214136/http://www.nationalreview.com/articles/222482/big-sister-watching-you/flashbackMay 11, 2011noAtlas Shruggedreceived positive reviews from a few publications, including praise from the noted book reviewerJohn Chamberlain (journalist)John Chamberlain,but Rand scholarMimi Reisel Gladsteinlater wrote that "reviewers seemed to vie with each other in a contest to devise the cleverest put-downs", calling it "execrable claptrap" and "a nightmare"; they said it was "written out of hate" and showed "remorseless hectoring and prolixity".AuthorFlannery O'Connorwrote in a letter to a friend that "The fiction of Ayn Rand is as low as you can get re fiction. I hope you picked it up off the floor of the subway and threw it in the nearest garbage pail."cite bookO'ConnorFlanneryThe Habit of Being: Letters of Flannery O'ConnorSallyFitzgeraldNew YorkFarrar, Straus, and Giroux19790-374-52104-218175642398

Rand's nonfiction received far fewer reviews than her novels had. The tenor of the criticism for her first nonfiction book,For the New Intellectual, was similar to that forAtlas Shrugged,harvnbGladstein1999119harvnbBurns2009193–194with philosopherSidney Hooklikening her certainty to "the way philosophy is written in the Soviet Union",cite newsSidneyHookSidney HookEach Man for Himself[[The New York Times Book Review]]April 9, 196128http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?resApril 15, 2011http://web.archive.org/web/20110511114045/http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?resMay 11, 2011noand authorGore Vidalcalling her viewpoint "nearly perfect in its immorality".cite bookGoreVidalGore VidalRocking the BoatTwo Immoralists: Orville Prescott and Ayn RandLittle, BrownBoston1962291123234Reprinted fromEsquire (magazine)Esquire, July 1961.Her subsequent books got progressively less attention from reviewers.

On the 100th anniversary of Rand's birth in 2005, Edward Rothstein, writing forThe New York Times, referred to her fictional writing as quaintutopian"retro fantasy" and programmaticneo-Romanticismof the misunderstood artist, while criticizing her characters' "isolated rejection of democratic society".cite newshttp://www.nytimes.com/2005/02/02/books/02rand.html?pagewantedThe New York TimesConsidering the Last Romantic, Ayn Rand, at 100EdwardRothsteinFebruary 2, 2005April 15, 2011http://web.archive.org/web/20110512144841/http://www.nytimes.com/2005/02/02/books/02rand.html?pagewantedMay 12, 2011noIn 2007, book critic Leslie Clark described her fiction as "romance novels with a patina ofpseudo-philosophy".cite newsLeslieClarkThe philosophical art of looking out number onehttp://www.heraldscotland.com/the-philosophical-art-of-looking-out-number-one-1.835066[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]]February 17, 2007April 2, 2010In 2009,GQ's critic columnist Tom Carson described her books as "capitalism's version of middlebrow religious novels" such asBen-Hur: A Tale of the ChristBen-Hurand theLeft Behindseries.cite journalhttp://www.gq.com/entertainment/books/200911/ayn-rand-dick-books-fountainhead?printableThe Bitch is BackAndrewCorsello[[GQ]]Condé Nast PublicationsOctober 27, 2009April 9, 2011http://web.archive.org/web/20110514133528/http://www.gq.com/entertainment/books/200911/ayn-rand-dick-books-fountainhead?printableMay 14, 2011no
article.heading: Popular interest
article.paragraph: File:Ayn Rand quote, American Adventure, Epcot Center, Walt Disney World.jpg.jpgthumbrightalt=An engraving in all capital letters that reads: "Throughout the centuries there were men who took first steps down new roads armed with nothing but their own vision." Ayn RandA quote from Rand's book ''The Fountainhead'', on the wall directly across from the entrance toThe American Adventure (Epcot)The American Adventurerotunda atWalt Disney World ResortWalt Disney World'sEpcot.In 1991, a survey conducted for theLibrary of Congressand theBook-of-the-Month Clubasked club members what the most influential book in the respondent's life was. Rand'sAtlas Shruggedwas the second most popular choice, after theBible.harvnbDoherty200711Rand's books continue to be widely sold and read, with over 29 million copies sold as of 2013 (with about 10% of that total purchased for free distribution to schools by theAyn Rand Institute).cite webhttp://ari.aynrand.org/media-center/press-releases/2013/05/14/ayn-rand-hits-a-million-againAyn Rand Hits a Million...Again!Ayn Rand InstituteMay 14, 2013April 21, 2014Although Rand's influence has been greatest in the United States, there has been international interest in her work.harvnbGladstein2003384–386;cite bookDelbroyBibekBibek DebroyAyn Rand—The Indian ConnectionAyn Rand at 100MachanTibor RTibor R. MachanNew Delhi, IndiaPragun Publications200681-89645-57-9768297422–4Rand's work continues to be among the top sellers among books in India.cite news[[Agence France-Presse]]/[[Jiji Press]]In India, Ayn Rand never out of style[[Japan Times]]June 2, 20124

Rand's contemporary admirers included fellow novelists, such asIra Levin,Kay Nolte SmithandL. Neil Smith, and later writers such asErika HolzerandTerry Goodkindhave been influenced by her.cite journalRiggenbachJeff[[The Journal of Ayn Rand Studies]]Ayn Rand's Influence on American Popular Fiction61Fall 200491–144http://www.aynrandstudies.com/jars/archives/jars6-1/jars6_1jriggenbach.pdfApril 20, 2011http://web.archive.org/web/20110514042655/http://www.aynrandstudies.com/jars/archives/jars6-1/jars6_1jriggenbach.pdfMay 14, 2011no41560271Other artists who have cited Rand as an important influence on their lives and thought includecomic bookartistSteve DitkoharvnbSciabarra20048–11and musicianNeil PeartofRush (band)Rush.cite journalSciabarraChris MatthewChris Matthew Sciabarra[[The Journal of Ayn Rand Studies]]Rand, Rush, and Rock41Fall 2002161–185http://www.nyu.edu/projects/sciabarra/essays/rush.htmApril 20, 2011Rand provided a positive view of business, and in response business executives and entrepreneurs have admired and promoted her work.harvnbBurns2009168–171John A. Allison IVJohn Allisonof BB&T andEd Sniderof Comcast Spectacor have funded the promotion of Rand's ideas,harvnbBurns2009298;harvnbBranden1986419whileMark Cuban, owner of the Dallas Mavericks, andJohn P. Mackey, CEO of Whole Foods, among others, have said they consider Rand crucial to their success.cite newshttp://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/15/business/15atlas.html?_rThe New York TimesAyn Rand's Literature of CapitalismHarrietRubinSeptember 15, 2007April 15, 2011http://web.archive.org/web/20110512144741/http://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/15/business/15atlas.html?_rMay 12, 2011no

Rand and her works have been referred to in a variety of media: on television shows including animated sitcoms, live-action comedies, dramas, and game shows,harvnbSciabarra20044–5as well as in movies and video games.harvnbBurns2009282She, or a character based on her, figures prominently (in positive and negative lights) in literary and science fiction novels by prominent American authors.harvnbSciabarra20043Nick Gillespie, editor in chief ofReason (magazine)Reason, has remarked that "Rand's is a tortured immortality, one in which she's as likely to be a punch line as a protagonist..." and that "jibes at Rand as cold and inhuman, run through the popular culture".cite episodeBook Bag: Marking the Ayn Rand Centennialhttp://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyIdDay to DayDay to DayNational Public RadioFebruary 2, 2005[[Alex Chadwick]] (host), Nick Gillespie (contributor)Two movies have been made about Rand's life. A 1997 documentary film,Ayn Rand: A Sense of Life, was nominated for theAcademy Award for Documentary Feature.harvnbGladstein1999128The Passion of Ayn Rand (film)The Passion of Ayn Rand, a 1999 television adaptation of theThe Passion of Ayn Rand (book)book of the same name, won several awards.harvnbGladstein2009122Rand's image also appears on aList of people on stamps of the United States#R1999Postage stamps and postal history of the United StatesU.S. postage stampdesigned by artistNick Gaetano.cite bookKrause-Minkus Standard Catalog of U.S. StampsMaurice D.Wozniak[[Krause Publications]]20015th0-87349-321-448663542380cite webhttp://www.virtualstampclub.com/us1999.htmlU.S. Stamp Schedule 1999September 22, 1999Virtual Stamp ClubAugust 12, 2013
article.heading: Political influence
article.paragraph: See alsoLibertarianism and ObjectivismAlthough she rejected the labels "Conservatism in the United Statesconservative" and "libertarian",harvnbBurns2009258;harvnbRand200573Rand has had continuing influence onright-wing politicsand libertarianism.Jim Powell (historian)Jim Powell, a senior fellow at theCato Institute, considers Rand one of the three most important women (along withRose Wilder LaneandIsabel Paterson) of modernAmerican libertarianism,cite journalPowellJimJim Powell (historian)Rose Wilder Lane, Isabel Paterson, and Ayn Rand: Three Women Who Inspired the Modern Libertarian Movementhttp://www.thefreemanonline.org/featured/rose-wilder-lane-isabel-paterson-and-ayn-rand-three-women-who-inspired-the-modern-libertarian-movement/[[The Freeman|The Freeman: Ideas on Liberty]]May 1996465322April 15, 2011http://web.archive.org/web/20110511104313/http://www.thefreemanonline.org/featured/rose-wilder-lane-isabel-paterson-and-ayn-rand-three-women-who-inspired-the-modern-libertarian-movement/May 11, 2011noandDavid Nolan (libertarian)David Nolan, one of the founders of theLibertarian Party (United States)Libertarian Party, stated that "without Ayn Rand, the libertarian movement would not exist".harvnbBranden1986414In his history of thelibertarian movement, journalistBrian Doherty (journalist)Brian Dohertydescribed her as "the most influential libertarian of the twentieth century to the public at large",and biographer Jennifer Burns referred to her as "the ultimate gateway drug to life on the right".harvnbBurns20094

article.paragraph: She faced intense opposition fromWilliam F. Buckley, Jr.and other contributors for theNational Reviewmagazine. They published numerous criticisms in the 1950s and 1960s byWhittaker Chambers,Garry Wills, andM. Stanton Evans. Nevertheless, her influence among conservatives forced Buckley and otherNational Reviewcontributors to reconsider how traditional notions of virtue and Christianity could be integrated with support for capitalism.harvnbBurns2004

The political figures who cite Rand as an influence are usually conservatives (often members of the United States Republican Party),harvnbDoherty200954despite Rand taking some positions that are atypical for conservatives, such as beingpro-choiceand an atheist.cite journalhttp://motherjones.com/media/2009/07/and-rand-playedAnd the Rand Played OnAmyBenfer[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]July–August 2009April 15, 2011http://web.archive.org/web/20110503215311/http://motherjones.com/media/2009/07/and-rand-playedMay 3, 2011noA 1987 article inThe New York Timesreferred to her as theReagan administration's "novelist laureate".harvnbBurns2009279RepublicanUnited States CongressCongressmenand conservativepunditshave acknowledged her influence on their lives and recommended her novels.harvnbGladstein2009124;harvnbHeller2009xi;harvnbDoherty200951;harvnbBurns2009283

Thelate-2000s financial crisisspurred renewed interest in her works, especiallyAtlas Shrugged, which some saw as foreshadowing the crisis,harvnbBurns2009283–284;harvnbDoherty200951–52;harvnbGladstein2009125and opinion articles compared real-world events with the plot of the novel.harvnbGladstein2009125;harvnbDoherty200954During this time, signs mentioning Rand and her fictional heroJohn Galtappeared atTea Party protests.harvnbDoherty200951–52There was also increased criticism of her ideas, especially from thepolitical left, with critics blaming the economic crisis on her support ofRational egoismselfishnessandfree markets, particularly through her influence onAlan Greenspan.harvnbBurns2009283For example,Mother Jones (magazine)Mother Jonesremarked that "Rand's particular genius has always been her ability to turn upside down traditional hierarchies and recast the wealthy, the talented, and the powerful as the oppressed",while equating Randian individual well-being with that of theVolkaccording to Goebbels. Corey Robin ofThe Nationalleged similarities between the "moral syntax of Randianism" and fascism.cite journalCoreyRobinGarbage and Gravitashttp://www.thenation.com/article/garbage-and-gravitas[[The Nation]]June 7, 2010April 15, 2011http://web.archive.org/web/20110514200011/http://www.thenation.com/article/garbage-and-gravitasMay 14, 2011no
article.heading: Academic reaction
article.paragraph: During Rand's lifetime her work received little attention from academic scholars.When the first academic book about Rand's philosophy appeared in 1971, its author declared writing about Rand "a treacherous undertaking" that could lead to "guilt by association" for taking her seriously.harvnbO'Neill19773A few articles about Rand's ideas appeared in academic journals before her death in 1982, many of them inThe Personalist.harvnbGladstein1999115One of these was "On the Randian Argument" by libertarian philosopherRobert Nozick, who argued that hermeta-ethicalargument is unsound and fails to solve theisought problemposed byDavid Hume.cite journalOn the Randian ArgumentNozickRobertRobert Nozick[[The Personalist]]Spring 197152282–304Some responses to Nozick by other academic philosophers were also published inThe Personalistarguing that Nozick misstated Rand's case.Academic consideration of Rand as a literary figure during her life was even more limited. Academic Mimi Gladstein was unable to find any scholarly articles about Rand's novels when she began researching her in 1973, and only three such articles appeared during the rest of the 1970s.harvnbGladstein2003373–374, 379–381

Since Rand's death, interest in her work has gradually increased.harvnbGladstein2009114–122;harvnbSalmieriGotthelf20051995;cite journalMcLemeeScotthttp://linguafranca.mirror.theinfo.org/9909/rand.htmlThe Heirs Of Ayn Rand: Has Objectivism Gone Subjective?[[Lingua Franca (magazine)|Lingua Franca]]September 19999645–55April 15, 2011http://web.archive.org/web/20110515004459/http://linguafranca.mirror.theinfo.org/9909/rand.htmlMay 15, 2011noHistorian Jennifer Burns has identified "three overlapping waves" of scholarly interest in Rand, the most recent of which is "an explosion of scholarship" since the year 2000.harvnbBurns2009295–296However, few universities currently include Rand or Objectivism as a philosophical specialty or research area, with many literature and philosophy departments dismissing her as a pop culture phenomenon rather than a subject for serious study.harvnbGladstein2009116

Gladstein,Chris Matthew Sciabarra,Allan Gotthelf,Edwin A. LockeandTara Smith (philosopher)Tara Smithhave taught her work in academic institutions. Sciabarra co-edits theJournal of Ayn Rand Studies, a nonpartisanpeer-reviewed journaldedicated to the study of Rand's philosophical and literary work.harvnbGladstein2009118In 1987 Gotthelf helped found the Ayn Rand Society with George Walsh and David Kelley, and has been active in sponsoring seminars about Rand and her ideas.harvnbGotthelf20002, 25;cite journalWilliamThomasAyn Rand Through Two LensesNavigatorApril 20003415–19http://www.atlassociety.org/on-ayn-rand-gotthelfSmith has written several academic books and papers on Rand's ideas, includingAyn Rand's Normative Ethics: The Virtuous Egoist, a volume on Rand's ethical theory published byCambridge University Press. Rand's ideas have also been made subjects of study atClemson UniversityClemsonandDuke UniversityDukeuniversities.cite newshttp://www.rutlandherald.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AIDAyn Rand at 100: An 'ism' struts its stuffBenjaminHarvey[[Rutland Herald]]Columbia News ServiceMay 15, 2005June 4, 2009Scholars of English and American literature have largely ignored her work,harvnbGladstein2003375although attention to her literary work has increased since the 1990s.harvnbGladstein2003384–391

Rand scholars Douglas Den Uyl andDouglas B. Rasmussen, while stressing the importance and originality of her thought, describe her style as "literary, hyperbolic and emotional".harvnbDen UylRasmussen1978203Philosopher Jack Wheeler says that despite "the incessant bombast and continuous venting of Randian rage", Rand's ethics are "a most immense achievement, the study of which is vastly more fruitful than any other in contemporary thought."Wheeler, Jack. "Rand and Aristotle". InharvnbDen UylRasmussen198696In theThe Literary Encyclopedia (English)Literary Encyclopediaentry for Rand written in 2001,John David Lewisdeclared that "Rand wrote the most intellectually challenging fiction of her generation".cite webLewisJohn DavidJohn David Lewishttp://www.litencyc.com/php/speople.php?rec[[The Literary Encyclopedia (English)|The Literary Encyclopedia]]Ayn RandAugust 2, 2009October 20, 2001In a 1999 interview in theChronicle of Higher Education, Sciabarra commented, "I know they laugh at Rand", while forecasting a growth of interest in her work in the academic community.cite journalSharletJeffJeff Sharlet (writer)[[The Chronicle of Higher Education]]http://chronicle.com/article/Ayn-Rand-Has-Finally-Caught/20237/Ayn Rand Has Finally Caught the Attention of ScholarsApril 9, 19994531A17–A18April 15, 2011

Libertarian philosopherMichael Huemerhas argued that very few people find Rand's ideas convincing, especially her ethics,cite webMichaelHuemerhttp://www.cato-unbound.org/2010/01/22/michael-huemer/why-ayn-rand-some-alternate-answersWhy Ayn Rand? Some Alternate Answers[[Cato Unbound]]January 22, 2010August 18, 2012which he believes is difficult to interpret and may lack logical coherence.cite journalMichaelHumerIs Benevolent Egoism Coherent?[[The Journal of Ayn Rand Studies]]32Spring 2002259–288http://aynrandstudies.com/jars/archives/jars3-2/jars3_2mhuemer.pdfhttp://wayback.archive.org/web/20110915095043/http://www.aynrandstudies.com/jars/archives/jars3-2/jars3_2mhuemer.pdfSeptember 15, 2011He attributes the attention she receives to her being a "compelling writer", especially as a novelist. Thus,Atlas Shruggedoutsells not only the works of other philosophers ofclassical liberalismsuch asLudwig von Mises,Friedrich Hayek, orFrederic Bastiat, but also Rand's own non-fiction works.

Political scientistCharles Murray (political scientist)Charles Murray, while praising Rand's literary accomplishments, criticizes her claim that her only "philosophical debt" was to Aristotle, instead asserting that her ideas were derivative of previous thinkers such asJohn LockeandFriedrich Nietzsche.cite webhttp://www.claremont.org/publications/crb/id.1708/article_detail.aspThe Claremont InstituteWho is Ayn Rand?CharlesMurray2010December 7, 2012https://web.archive.org/web/20131501431000/http://www.claremont.org/publications/crb/id.1708/article_detail.aspDecember 1, 2013

Although Rand maintained that Objectivism was an integrated philosophical system, philosopher Robert H. Bass has argued that her central ethical ideas are inconsistent and contradictory to her central political ideas.cite journalRobert H.BassEgoism versus Rights[[The Journal of Ayn Rand Studies]]72Spring 2006329–349http://aynrandstudies.com/jars/archives/jars7-2/jars7_2rbass1.pdfhttp://wayback.archive.org/web/20121105111109/http://www.aynrandstudies.com/jars/archives/jars7-2/jars7_2rbass1.pdfNovember 5, 2012
article.heading: Objectivist movement
article.paragraph: MainObjectivist movementIn 1985, Rand's heir Leonard Peikoff established theAyn Rand Institute, a nonprofit organization dedicated to promoting Rand's ideas and works. In 1990, philosopherDavid Kelleyfounded the Institute for Objectivist Studies, now known asThe Atlas Society.harvnbBurns2009280–281;harvnbGladstein200919, 114In 2001 historian John McCaskey organized the Anthem Foundation for Objectivist Scholarship, which provides grants for scholarly work on Objectivism in academia.harvnbGladstein2009117The charitable foundation ofBB&T Corporationhas also given grants for teaching Rand's ideas or works. TheUniversity of Texas at Austin, theUniversity of Pittsburgh, andUniversity of North Carolina at Chapel Hillare among the schools that have received grants. In some cases these grants have been controversial due to their requiring research or teaching related to Rand.harvnbGladstein2009116–117;harvnbBurns2009297
